item.title: Updates: Charles III Expresses ‘Profound Sorrow’ Over Queen’s Death in First Speech as King
item.description: His remarks capped a solemn day of remembrance after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II. The country now enters a mourning period that continues until after her funeral.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II: The One Constant in an Inconstant World
item.description: From fading empire to the Cold War to 1970s turmoil to Brexit to Covid, “she was always there.” What will Britain, and the world, do without her?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip amid memorial bouquets at Buckingham Palace in 1997, the year Princess Diana died.

item.title: In His First Speech, King Charles III Pledges Service to Britain
item.description: On a day of mourning in the U.K. after the death of Queen Elizabeth, Charles’s ascent to the throne was a symbol of the continuity of the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III outside Buckingham Palace on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Urges European Nations: Don’t Let Putin ‘Bully’ Over Energy Prices
item.description: Antony J. Blinken, the secretary of state, said Washington would stand with European allies as Russia seeks to “weaponize” energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for food distribution at a destroyed apartment complex in Chernihiv, northern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Balmoral, a Cherished Royal Getaway in Scotland, Becomes a Place of Pilgrimage
item.description: ‘If she had to go, this was the place,’ one visitor said. ‘She loved it.’
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Paying respect on Friday outside the gate of Balmoral Castle in Scotland after the death of Queen Elizabeth.

item.title: Long an Uneasy Prince, King Charles III Takes On a Role He Was Born To
item.description: Once an awkward, self-doubting young man, he comes to the throne, at 73, as a self-assured, gray-haired eminence.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: As heir to the throne, Charles took on several of the queen’s duties in recent years. In May, he delivered the Queen’s Speech during the state opening of Parliament.

item.title: Camilla Becomes Queen Consort, Capping Years of Image Restoration
item.description: Upon Queen Elizabeth’s death, there was no question that as her son became King Charles III, Camilla would become queen consort. Elizabeth put the issue of Camilla’s role to rest earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Charles, left, chats with Camilla Parker Bowles at a polo match, circa 1972.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth, and the Power and Limitations of Inspiring Women
item.description: Changing minds can be powerful, but history shows that changing societies takes more.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Piccadilly Circus in central London on Thursday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96; Was Britain’s Longest-Reigning Monarch
item.description: She ruled for seven decades, unshakably committed to the rituals of her role amid epic social and economic change and family scandal.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2012.

item.title: 2 Years After Deadly Fistfights, India and China Pull Back From Border
item.description: The two sides, after 16 rounds of talks, made an announcement a week before their leaders will meet in Uzbekistan.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: An Indian Army convoy on a highway bordering China in 2020.

item.title: Thousands of Angry Indonesians Gather to Protest Rising Fuel Prices
item.description: Labor activists, workers and students are demanding a reversal of an economic policy that the government says is necessary but remains deeply unpopular.
item.dc:creator: Dera Menra Sijabat, Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: Student activists in Jakarta, Indonesia’s capital, during a rally against higher fuel prices on Thursday.

item.title: Volker Türk, an Austrian Diplomat, Takes U.N. Human Rights Post
item.description: One of Volker Türk’s toughest challenges will be determining what to do about a highly critical report on China that his predecessor, Michelle Bachelet, released just before departing.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Volker Türk, 57, is not widely known outside the United Nations, but he was seen as the front-runner in a field of 13 candidates interviewed for the role.

item.title: Why the U.S. Is Being Ominously Compared to Hungary and Turkey
item.description: A conversation with Max Fisher, who covers the decline of democracy around the world.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell and Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump, like other leaders around the world who have attacked democratic institutions, has appealed to supporters by promising to defeat internal threats to the country.

item.title: Ukraine Attacks Russia in the Kharkiv Region, Swiftly Making Gains
item.description: Sweeping south from positions in the Kharkiv region in Ukraine’s northeast, Ukrainian forces have made their largest gains since routing Russia from Kyiv in April.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Marco Hernandez
item.media:description: Ukrainian fighters in Kharkiv on Friday. President Volodymyr Zelensky said his military had captured large chunks of occupied territory in the north.

item.title: King Charles Names William and Kate Prince and Princess of Wales
item.description: In a palace statement, they indicated they would honor William’s late mother while still forging their own path.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:credit: Ashley Crowden/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Now prince and princess of Wales, Kate and William said they “are focused on deepening the trust and respect of the people of Wales over time.”

item.title: Russia Holds First Elections Since Ukraine Invasion
item.description: Voters are choosing local and regional governments, but the ranks of opposition candidates have been severely depleted by jail and exile.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Anton Troianovski and Alina Lobzina
item.media:description: Ballot boxes at a polling station in Moscow, on Friday.

item.title: King Charles to Replace Queen Elizabeth on Bank Notes and Coins
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II faced right on British coins. Her son and successor might face the other way.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Since the 17th century, British monarchs have faced the opposite direction of their predecessors on coins.

item.title: King Charles III’s Speech: Full Transcript
item.description: King Charles III honored his mother in his first speech to the nation as sovereign.
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III outside Buckingham Palace on Friday.

item.title: In London, Mourning, Remembrance and Tributes. And Some Shrugs.
item.description: Though mourning and grief were visible in Britain’s capital on Friday, some young Britons were more muted in their reaction to an institution that many called increasingly irrelevant.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, Isabella Kwai and Saskia Solomon
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Queen Elizabeth is displayed at Victoria Station in London.

item.title: King Charles III Will Be Announced in His New Role on Saturday
item.description: The ceremony will be televised for the first time, the royal family confirmed to the Press Association.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III, at Buckingham Palace on Friday, became Britain’s new monarch immediately after his mother’s death. But his new role will be formally recognized on Saturday.

item.title: What Will Happen to Queen Elizabeth’s Corgis?
item.description: Wherever the dogs end up, they may need to become accustomed to a home that is less luxurious than a royal castle.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth with four of her corgis in London in 1969.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Renews British Empire Debate in Africa
item.description: While some in Africa paid tribute to the deceased monarch, others stressed Britain’s violent colonial history on the continent.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Lynsey Chutel and Elian Peltier
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Mau Mau fighters detained in 1952 in Kenya, a British colony at the time. An anticolonial rebellion was suppressed shortly after Queen Elizabeth II ascended to the British throne.

item.title: Harry Leaves Balmoral Castle, With Uncertain Plans Ahead
item.description: The Duke of Sussex was among the members of the royal family who traveled to the estate in Scotland where Queen Elizabeth II died.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prince Harry on Friday before boarding a flight to London from Aberdeen Airport in Scotland.

item.title: Artists discuss how they turned the queen into an icon.
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II of Britain was one of the world’s most photographed and painted people. Three artists explain how they made portraits of the monarch that stood out from the crowd.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Putin Critic Aleksei Navalny Says Russia Revoked His Attorney-Client Privilege
item.description: Mr. Navalny said on Twitter that the prison administration had accused him of committing unspecified crimes by communicating with “accomplices through lawyers.”
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Alexei A. Navalny appeared in court via video in May. He said he had been informed that all incoming and outgoing communication with his lawyers would be subjected to “a three-day check.”

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Draws A More Muted Response in India
item.description: India declared a day of mourning, but the British colonial era evokes uncomfortable memories.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Reading news of Queen Elizabeth’s death in the city of Chennai in Tamil Nadu, India.

item.title: Mourning Queen Elizabeth: Buckingham Palace Shares Tribute Details
item.description: The palace released the protocol for floral tributes, the closing of royal residences and a period of mourning to mark the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flowers for the queen outside of Buckingham Palace on Thursday night.

item.title: For Australians, Too, It’s the End of an Era
item.description: “I don’t think we’ll ever have the security again that we had with her,” said one Australian about the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Laying flowers for Queen Elizabeth in Canberra on Friday.

item.title: Premier League Soccer Games Postponed Out of Respect for the Queen
item.description: The league was one of many sports organizations in Britain to alter its schedule after the death of Queen Elizabeth II. Others will play on this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith and Tariq Panja
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Players for Manchester United observed a moment of silence in honor of Queen Elizabeth II before their match on Thursday night.

item.title: Filthy Plane Videos Ignite Debate About Airline Cleanliness
item.description: Recent social media posts suggest that the days of clean flights may be going the way of masks. And they’ve ignited a debate about who bears responsibility.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy

item.title: Kim Jong-un Says North Korea Will ‘Never Give Up’ Its Nuclear Weapons
item.description: The law authorizes a nuclear strike if an enemy tries to remove Kim Jong-un from power, the North’s state media reported.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, said Thursday that there would “no longer be any bargaining over our nuclear power,” according to state media, which released this photo.

item.title: The U.S. and Russia clash at the U.N. over military aid.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Vasily Nebenzya, Russia’s ambassador to the United Nations, at a Security Council meeting in New York on Wednesday

item.title: Rising energy prices amid a standoff with Russia over Ukraine are pushing Europe to spend big again.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A view of a darkened Athens last month. The Greek government is both subsidizing energy bills and pushing people to conserve power.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A special edition of the Briefing on the death of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in the Throne Room at Buckingham Palace in June 1953, after her coronation.

item.title: As Crises Mount, Europe Turns Once Again to Big Spending
item.description: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine and rising energy prices are rapidly overturning European economic orthodoxy, with barely a peep of dissent.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany, center, at a Siemens Energy plant in Muelheim an der Ruhr, last month.

item.title: Meghan and Harry’s Children Could Now Inherit Royal Titles
item.description: Now that their grandfather is king — and if the royal family adheres to convention — the children of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex should become Prince Archie and Princess Lilibet.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, during the queen’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations in London in June.

item.title: Grief for the Queen Mixes With Criticism of the Monarchy
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II was remembered by ordinary Britons, world leaders and other royals for her grace, humor and longevity. Others had more conflicted views on the monarchy.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Laying flowers outside the British Embassy in Washington on Thursday after the death of Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: In a Divided Britain, Near Unity in Admiration of the Queen
item.description: Across London, conversations reflected how deeply the loss had touched the nation — and how fundamental Elizabeth’s role had been in the national identity.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Saskia Solomon, Emma Bubola and Isabella Kwai
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A portrait of Queen Elizabeth II in Piccadilly Circus in London on Thursday.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth’s Death Comes at Moment of Uncertainty for Britain
item.description: There is no analogous British figure who will be mourned as deeply, or whose death will provoke a greater reckoning with the identity and future of the country.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II in 2018.

item.title: A Kick at the Door, a Knife in the Hand: The Saskatchewan Murders
item.description: As investigators pore over a sprawling and complex trail of crimes, a clearer picture is emerging of the stabbing rampage on an Indigenous reserve in Canada.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky, Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil in Prince Albert, Saskatchewan, on Wednesday.

item.title: The Queen Met 13 Sitting U.S. Presidents, Who Basked in Her Global Prestige
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II was a gracious host and guest over the last seven decades, even when faced with protocol mistakes and awkward missteps.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: President Ronald Reagan with Queen Elizabeth II at Windsor Castle in 1982.

item.title: Biden and Former Presidents Give Statements on Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: Six of the American leaders she met during her long life offer remembrances of her and their encounters.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II Dies at 96
item.description: Plus the Solomon Islands postpones its election and tycoons leave China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Eddie Mulholland/Agence France-Presse, via Pool/AFP Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II was the longest-serving monarch in British history.

item.title: The U.S. announces sanctions on Iranian companies involved in Russia drone sales.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Iranian Army Office, via Agence France-Presse—Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo released by the Iranian Army shows drones in an underground base in July. Russia received its first delivery of Iranian drones in late August.

item.title: Blinken’s Surprise Visit to Ukraine Offers Aid and Encouragement
item.description: At a “pivotal moment” as a counteroffensive makes gains, the secretary of state pledged $2.8 billion more in military aid to Ukraine and allies.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken visiting the devastated city of Irpin during his surprise trip to Ukraine Thursday.

item.title: 9 Books About Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: Elizabeth, famously reticent during her decades in the public eye, was a source of fascination for many. These books offer a deeper understanding of her life, family and world.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Mourning Queen Elizabeth II, in Photos
item.description: The death of the queen marks the loss of a revered monarch, the only one most Britons have ever known.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles III outside Buckingham Palace on Friday.

item.title: President Biden Remembers Queen Elizabeth II Who ‘Defined an Era’
item.description: Biden first met Queen Elizabeth in 1982 during a trip to Britain as a young senator. His most recent meeting came about a year ago, in Cornwall, England.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Queen Elizabeth II last year at Windsor Castle outside London.

item.title: Britain’s National Anthem Will Become ‘God Save the King’
item.description: Many small changes are expected in Britain in the coming weeks, but one will be only obvious only when it’s sung: For the first time since 1952, the anthem will go ‘God save the king.’
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Oxford Street in London decked out in May for Queen Elizabeth’s Platinum Jubilee celebrations.

item.title: Tropical Storm Kay Moves Up Baja California’s Western Coast
item.description: Kay was causing heavy rain and flooding in Mexico and was moving into Southern California and Arizona on Friday, the National Weather Service said.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:description: People mooring small boats in port before the arrival of Kay in Ensenada, Baja California, Mexico, on Thursday.

item.title: Conditions at Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Plant Are ‘Unsustainable,’ U.N. Watchdog Warns
item.description: Cut off from the country’s electric grid, the plant is relying on an emergency measure that it is not designed to keep up for long, while shells continue to rain down.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Rafael Mariano Grossi, director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, visited the nuclear plant in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: Olivia Colman and Claire Foy on Playing Queen Elizabeth II on ‘The Crown’
item.description: In “The Queen” and “The Crown,” actors took different approaches to get under the skin of the enigmatic monarch.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Olivia Colman in her Emmy Award-winning portrayal of Queen Elizabeth II in Season 3 of “The Crown.”

item.title: Operation London Bridge: What Happens After Queen Elizabeth’s Death
item.description: The death of Queen Elizabeth II has set in motion a meticulously choreographed process — known as Operation London Bridge — that the palace, and the nation, has spent decades planning.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II waved from the balcony of Buckingham Palace in 1953 after her coronation. She was Britain’s longest-reigning monarch.

item.title: Failure to Slow Warming Will Set Off Climate ‘Tipping Points,’ Scientists Say
item.description: As global warming passes certain limits, dire changes will probably become irreversible, the researchers said, including the loss of polar ice sheets and the death of coral reefs.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A summer sunset over Disko Bay in Ilulissat, Greenland.

item.title: How Queen Elizabeth II’s Style Shaped the World
item.description: The longest-serving British monarch let her clothes do the talking for her.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II inspecting a guard of honor during her Silver Jubilee visit to Scotland in 1977.
